","erg":[],"campus":{"name":"Kensington"}},"additional_information":"This course is offered as General Education.","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Kensington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GENE0050","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENE0050 - Space Mining","description":"

Engineering is the application of scientific principles to solve real-world problems and is behind the rise of recent and world-changing technologies such as smartphones, electric cars and artificial intelligence. Space mining is possibly one of the most world-changing ideas and most of the focus has been on solving the engineering challenges. Some say that space mining is the way to create a society of limitless resources and change the way that the world can operate, others say that mining space resources will cause crashes in gold, platinum and multiple other markets, creating havoc here on Earth. Issues like these are why subjects like space mining are in need of people from other disciplines, to help understand all of the other problems in this and similar fields and how those problems might be solved.


In this course, we will explore what opportunities this and other world-changing engineering challenges have for those who are not engineers. Students will be taken through the engineering lifecycle of new technologies and encouraged to think about how their unique skills can be applied to these projects.

contentlets.description:
Engineering is the application of scientific principles to solve real-world problems and is behind the rise of recent and world-changing technologies such as smartphones, electric cars and artificial intelligence. Space mining is possibly one of the most world-changing ideas and most of the focus has been on solving the engineering challenges. Some say that space mining is the way to create a society of limitless resources and change the way that the world can operate, others say that mining space resources will cause crashes in gold, platinum and multiple other markets, creating havoc here on Earth. Issues like these are why subjects like space mining are in need of people from other disciplines, to help understand all of the other problems in this and similar fields and how those problems might be solved.

In this course, we will explore what opportunities this and other world-changing engineering challenges have for those who are not engineers. Students will be taken through the engineering lifecycle of new technologies and encouraged to think about how their unique skills can be applied to these projects.
contentlets.title: Space Mining

honours).","campus":"","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GENE1015","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENE1015 - Environmental Sustainability - Methods, Tools, Management","description":"

 


An introduction to Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) principles and the social, economic and political context in which they have arisen, and in which they are implemented. It introduces methods, techniques and tools used by regional and corporate environmental managers to implement ESD principles in organisations and regions. These methods and tools include a range of environmental assessment techniques that can be applied at a product level (Life Cycle Assessment), at a corporate and regional level (Materials Flow Analysis) and at a regional and national level (Environmental Footprint and Input-Output Analysis). The course will introduce principles of Industrial Ecology (IE) and the preparation of Environmental Impact Statements (EIS), Environmental Management Systems (EMS) and Environmental Reports (ER).

contentlets.description: An introduction to Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) principles and the social, economic and political context in which they have arisen, and in which they are implemented. It introduces methods, techniques and tools used by regional and corporate environmental managers to implement ESD principles in organisations and regions. These methods and tools include a range of environmental assessment techniques that can be applied at a product level (Life Cycle Assessment), at a corporate and regional level (Materials Flow Analysis) and at a regional and national level (Environmental Footprint and Input-Output Analysis). The course will introduce principles of Industrial Ecology (IE) and the preparation of Environmental Impact Statements (EIS), Environmental Management Systems (EMS) and Environmental Reports (ER).

","url":"https://www.engineering.unsw.edu.au/","name_url":"Faculty of Engineering","name_no_url":""}],"requisites":[],"unit_offering":[],"academic_calendar_tooltip":"","academic_item_type":"Course","no_enrolment":"false","offering_detail":{"key":"ugrd","fees":{},"offering_terms":"","fees_table":"","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"This course is offered as General Education.","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GENE1500","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENE1500 - Creative Entrepreneurship","description":"

What is creativity? What is entrepreneurship? Why do they matter? In this course, you will identify, analyse and propose a solution to a meaningful unsolved problem in the world for an identified market segment. The course runs in an experiential mode, and you will form multidisciplinary teams to tackle their chosen problem, guided by entrepreneurship mentors and UNSW alumni who are running their own startup. Practical tools and protocols will be introduced for critically developing solution concepts, performing competitive analyses, building mindsets, skills, creativity and problem-solving, motivating and developing others, networking, building effective cross-disciplinary teams, designing experiments to validate concepts and rapid prototyping. You will then learn pitching and visual and graphic design skills, learning how to communicate influentially.


After this course, you will have (i) a changed mindset, so that you can experience the world and your entire study program from an entrepreneur’s perspective; (ii) sharpened skills in finding problems worth solving, mobilising people and resources to solve them, selling your ideas and skills and creating value; and (iii) a smaller step to creating your own first start-up, with mentors, support structures and fellow UNSW students to bring your ideas and companies to life.

This course can be taken by Faculty of Engineering students as a General Education course.

Practical tools and protocols will be introduced for critically developing solution concepts, performing competitive analyses, building mindsets, skills, creativity and problem-solving, motivating and developing others, networking, building effective cross-disciplinary teams, designing experiments to validate concepts and rapid prototyping. You will then learn pitching and visual and graphic design skills, learning how to communicate influentially.

After this course, you will have (i) a changed mindset, so that you can experience the world and your entire study program from an entrepreneur’s perspective; (ii) sharpened skills in finding problems worth solving, mobilising people and resources to solve them, selling your ideas and skills and creating value; and (iii) a smaller step to creating your own first start-up, with mentors, support structures and fellow UNSW students to bring your ideas and companies to life.

This course can be taken by Faculty of Engineering students as a General Education course.
contentlets.title: Creative Entrepreneurship
